MONDAY, JANUARY 23, 1905.

div.head: RUSSIA'S PLIGHT.
div.p: Every fresh telegram bears witness to the acute state of unrest in Russia, and this morning's despatches from St. Petersburg show that the Tsar has had thousands of his hapless subjects slaughtered in order to preserve his autocracy. The butchery of the populace yester day afternoon in the streets of the Russian capital is a striking commentary on the Tsar's answer to the demands of the Zemstvos delegates a few weeks ago, when he offered as a counter attraction to the franchise, "civil tranquillity and the uninterrupted satisfaction of the daily needs of the people." But neither the empty words of the Tsar's decree nor the ruthless destruction of the hapless workmen yesterday will have any effect in quashing the revolution, although it may be postponed. If the habitually brutal methods of Russian officialdom are successful, the revolutionary movement may be crushed for the time being, for rulers often go very near the precipice without falling over. On the other hand, it is by no means impossible that the events of yesterday after- Loon may precipitate a really serious crisis. Suppose the news of the massacre is quick ly disseminated throughout the provinces and some sudden madness were to seize upon the peasantry, who for the first time saw their "Little Father" revealed in his true colors. In such a case it is very possible to imagine a general revolt taking place in which al the other disaffected elements in the Empire, from Poland to Russian Armenia, and from Finland to the Jewish Pale, would spring into life. But it may well be doubted whether an immediate and general revolutionary movement is possible, for while war is going on the ins tinct of national self-preservation seems to keep down rebellion even in States whose gene ral condition makes for revolution.

The fall of Port Arthur has no doubt been a great factor in bringing about the present crisis, for it has brought home to the people the real position of affairs in the Far East, which has hitherto been obscured by the mendacious optimism of an inspired Press. They see that trade is falling, that employment is evermore scarce, that factories are closing, and that a state of semi-starvation exists in many rural districts; and they ask themselves for what purpose is this war Their own country is not threatened, and like the rest of the world they cannot understand what business their Government has in Manchuria at all. Accordingly they detest this unnecessary war, and their feeling is shown in the increasing difficulty which the Russian War Office experiences in getting the Reservists to join the colors. But there are even graver elements of disaffection at work among other great sections of the population, besides the actual Russians themselves. The last ten years has seen the growth within Russia ot a vast number of political enemies to the Russian Government. The policy of forcible Russifi cation has been carried out relentlessly, and apparently successfully, but not without much heart-burning. The best known case is that. of Finland, but other non-Russian nationalities have suffered almost as much. The Finns cannot revolt, but it is impossible to doubt that the dearest wish of the majority of the population is to escape from the iron circle of the Empire which is oppressing them. The Poles remain, as always, irreconcilable, even though they may consider that the Russian Government treats them better than does the German. These cases are patent; but it must also be remembered that the Bussification of the Baltic provinces, and the cold shoulder shown to the German and Lutheran elements in those districts, have produced anything but loyalty and confidence in an important, if numerically small, class. Something of the same kind has been going on on the other side of the Empire. The Armenians were once held in great esteem in Russia, Loris Melikhof actually rising to the very highest place in the bureaucracy. Now, however, the Armenians receive little fa vor, and the whole property of the Ar menian Church in Russia has been con fiscated in order to force them to enter the Orthodox Communion. The Armenians bear the persecution ill, and must now be counted among the disaffected sub-nationalities in Russia. Lastly, there are the Jews. With the massacre of Kishineff before their eyes, and the whole terrible story of the Anti-Jewish movement, can we wonder that they are restless and unfriendly? But in Russia the disaffection of the Jews does not mean, as it would in France or Germany, the disaffection of a small, if powerful, body. It means the hostility of several millions of men concentrated in a special area. The fact is that in Russia just now only the Slavonic and Tartar elements are allowed to come to the front, while the men of the other nationalities, unless they become members of the Orthodox Church, are depressed, and even persecuted. As a result, the political power of Russia and her administrative effi ciency have greatly suffered, while at the same time a sense of oppression has invaded bodies of men who in a former geueration were good Russians. Never, indeed, has the political folly of persecution, civil and reli gious, been made more plain. In addition to these dangers of a racial nature must be reckoned those which come from the growth of Socialism and Nihilism within the Russian body politic. The Russian Nihilist may be less dangerous than he was; but the growth of Socialism and of liberal ideas has been steadily progressing. And the Russian revolutionary does not do things by halves. The man who wants revolution in Russia does not mind with whom he co-operates in order to get it, and yesterday afternoon's massacre will weld together the numerous dissatisfied elements of Russian society against the ruthless and wicked despotism of Russian Administration.

div.head: OPEN REVOLUTION IN RUSSIA. PEOPLE'S APPEAL TO THE TSAR. CONFLICTS WITH TROOPS. - THOUSANDS KILLED. INDESCRIBABLE SCENES. - A NIGHT OF HORROR.

div.p: The situation here is most serious. The town is in partial darkness. The papers will probably be unable to appear. The civil employes at the Arsenal have joined the strikers. It is feared that the railway and telegraph operators will also join. A monster demonstration was held on Sunday in front of the Winter Palace, in order to present a petition to the Tsar. The petition, which was the most remarkable and outspoken document ever presented to an autocrat, declared that the people were insulted and treated like slaves, burdened with labour beyond their strength, stifled by despotism and the intolerable yoke of officialdom the injustice of which had reached its limit. Death was preferable to the fearful sufferings of the people. National representation was indispensable, immediate convocation of the representatives of all classes was the sole balm for the people's wounds. The petition says "Satisfy these demands and you make Russia happy and glorious. If you do not reply to the people's prayer, we prefer to die in the Square before your Palace.
The Prefect has issued a notice forbidding gatherings and processions, which workmen and the public are warned to avoid, as the employment of the military may cause accidents.
(Reuter.)

The prefect's notice was issued especially in view of the notification that 400,000 men are to march on Sunday afternoon to the Palace. They will be headed by a young priest, Father Gapon, in canonicals with crucifix, who is heart and soul in the movement. The workmen will insist upon seeing the Tsar himself.

It is noteworthy that the garrison here is about 40,000, largely composed of reservists. Hitherto the police have been absolutely passive. People are nervous and excited. Everyone is buying candles anticipating a stoppage of the gas and electric light. The newspapers have not been published.
A deputation of three workmen has gone to Tsarskoe Selo, with the object of trying to deliver the text of the petition, so as to enable the Tsar to consider it before the monster demonstration.
Father Gapon has selected 400 picked men to act as a bodyguard to the Tsar if the latter consents to meet the people. Gapon also has a personal bodyguard of 50 men in order to prevent his arrest.

All the cavalry regiments are concentrated here, from the surrounding barracks. Other regiments are being hurried up from Reval, Riga and elsewhere, as it is feared that the troops of the ordinary garrison would not fire on the demonstrators in the event of disorders.
(Reuter.)
The strikes are spreading, but no disturbances have occurred. (Havas.)
Several conflicts took place about 1 o'clock. It is stated that 80 of the strikers have been killed or wounded.
The Tsar remained at Tsarkoe Selo.
The Pope Gapon has been arrested.
The effervescence is general. The disturbances continue. (Havas.)
About 2 o clock the crowd invaded the approaches to the Winter Palace. The troops fired, 130 men and women being killed.
At 3.40 p.m. a conflict on Nevsky Prospect caused the deaths of thirty people.
Pope Gapon was not arrested ; he is wounded. Another priest Pope Serge, has been killed.
The workmen are barricading themselves in the Vassili Ostroff quarter.
It is rumoured that they have taken possession of the dynamite factory.
The troops are bivouacking.
It is believed that the number of killed and wounded amounts to several thousands. (H.)

Early in the morning ike Cossacks and other troops marched to the Winter Palace. Detachments of cavalry and infantry, each 150 strong, were stationed at various points of the city, but the artillery were concealed from view. 15,000 strikers started from the Neva works for the Winter Palace. Their route was barred by Cossacks, who fired three volleys in blank, charged the strikers with heavy whips, and finally drove back the demonstrators. It is unknown bow many were killed and injured.

A furious conflict took place between the soldiers and the strikers round the Winter Palace square. The troops, who were driven hack by the weight of the mob, fired repeatedly and finally dispersed the crowd. There were 150 killed and wounded. The strikers are now infuriated and are erecting wire entanglements, tearing down the telegraph poles, and raising barricades. They are organising an armed resistance. Sanguinary conflicts are taking place all over the city.
The Police Superintendent is among the killed and Father Gapon among the wounded.

(Later). Fatal conflicts between the strikers are taking place in every quarter of the city. The excitement is increasing. The crowd on Nicholas Bridge was stopped by the infantry and Uhlan Cossacks. The strikers appealed to the soldiers not to shoot their brothers. The infantry laid down their rifles but the Cossasks charged, wounding many. The Tsar remains at Tsarkoe Selo.

Many women and children have been killed and wounded. The scenes are indescribable. The air is rent with cries of women and the angry shouts of men. The city appears to be plunged in an open revolution. A night of horror is in prospect. (Reuter.)
The mob has erected two barricades at Basilisland from which they refuse to retreat despite the repeated volleys of the troops. They are also trying to erect barricades on the Nevsky Prospect.

At five o'clock the hiring was going on in every quarter of the city. The troops were firing recklessly, but one regiment is reported to have refused to fire. All classes appear inflamed alike. A number of wounded officers fell into the hands of the mob. Their swords and epaulettes were torn off. The ambulances are busy everywhere. (Reuter.)
There was a lull in the fighting in the centre of the city during the evening, but continuous firing was heard in the workers' quarter at Basilislaud, which is plunged in darkness.
An accurate estimate of the casualties is impossible, but it is believed they number l,500.

It is rumoured that a force of strikers, marching on Tsarskoe Selo, were driven back by the troops alter a sanguinary conflict. The centre of the city was practically deserted during the evening, except for the troops who were camped in the snow. Some infantry have been withdrawn and replaced by bluejackets.
The troops destroyed the barricades at Basilisland soon alter their erection, killing 30 persons. (Reuter.)
The troops prevented the rioters from going to Tsarkoe Selo. (Havas.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET. ANOTHER JAPANESE SCARE.

div.p: The "Times" has reason to believe that Admiral Rodjestvensky will not attempt to reach the Far East for at least three months.(Reuter.)
The "Times" says that Admiral Rodjestvensky intends cruising in the western waters of the Indian Ocean, thereby reliering France from her awkward position. (Reuter.)
A collier which has arrived here reports that the Baltic Fleet left Madagascar on the 14th inst.
The fleet prepared for action on the 13th in consequence of rumours that the Japanese were approaching. (Reuter.)
Four Japanese warships have been sighted off the Lankave Islands 40 miles north of Penang. (Reuter.)
M. Loubet has asked M. Rouvier to form the Cabinet (Havas.)
President Loubet has summoned M. Rouvier. (Reuter.)
M. Rouvier has practically completed his Cabinet. The members have decided to adhere to M. Combes' programme.
M. Delcasse is the Minister for Foreign Affairs. (Reuter.)
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught have left for Tunis. (Havas.)
The Nubia (Sudan) Development. Co. (Ltd.) announce the third call of 5s. per share, making the shares of the company fully paid.

div.head: Salt and Soda Co
div.p: Mr. E C. Friend, manager of the salt works at Mex, is leaving the service of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company very shortly.

div.head: Arrest of Young Turk
div.p: Capt. Ahmed Bey Said, the alleged "Young Turk," arrested in the Splendid Bar at Cairo last week, was set at liberty on Saturday afternoon.

div.head: Abbas Helmy Theatre
div.p: Signora Gemma Belincione will leave Venice to-morrow en route for Alexandria, where this celebrated Italian singer has been engaged for the Abbas Helmy Theatre.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On the 19th inst. 15 vessels passed through the Canal, 10 British, 2 French, 1 Austrian, 2 Swedish. The receipts for the day were frs. 484,450.03, making the total amount received in dues from 1st inst. frs. 7,201,701.98.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre
div.p: As their stay is drawing to a close, we should advise all, while there is yet time, to go to the Alhambra and hear the clever duettists Raphael and Colombel, who are taking the place by storm. The fact that they appeared at the Alhambra in London for close on three months is a sufficient indication of their talents.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain neccessary limits - free discussion

div.head: CAIRO JOURNALISM.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir,—I beg to enclose the copy of a letter, which I have sent to the Managing Editor of the "Egyptian Graphic," and I hope that in the interests of every British subject, as well as those of justice and fair play, you may see your way to inserting it in the columns of your worthy and esteemed paper, which has always to my knowledge (of 20 years) refrained from what can only be designated as "stabs in the dark." Thanking you in anticipation,
I am,
Yours very truly,

div.head: COPY
div.p: Cairo, 22nd January, 1905.
Monsieur Alfred Grégoire,
Managing Editor
"Egyptian Graphic," Cairo.

As through the medium of the "Egyptian Graphic" No. 3 of 15th inst., of which periodical you are the managing editor, you have thought it to utter a grossly libellous and defamatory article against me in my proper name:-

I hereby give you the opportunity of publishing not only in the "Graphic," but in the un-mentioned, an article which shall, as far as possible, amend the damage you have done me, together with your humble apology for the scurrilous, dastardly and cowardly attack made, without the slightest provocation, upon the reputation of a person you have had no dealings with, either directly or indirectly, and, evidently, do not even know.

I demand also the name of the actual writer of the article in question, and I will then decide upon what further action I shall take in the matter, reserving now to myself my rights to sue you for damages or otherwise.
I am,
J. W, Conodon.
(A British Subject).
The "Egyptian Gazette"
"L'Egypte"
"Le Progrès"
"El Ahram"
"El Mokattam."
(A similar letter has been sent to Messrs. Rizzo & Co.)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: A meeting of the Municipal Commission will be held at 4 o'clock next Wednesday, afternoon, when the following matters will be discussed:
1. Communications diverses.
2. Organisation des Services.
3. Classement du personnel.
4. Question relative aux membres provisoires de la Délégation.
5. Proposition do M. Cumbo, tendant à l'élaboration d'un arrête prescrivant le badigeonnage des maisons.
6. Proposition de Mr. Zouro au sujet des pouls publics et projet de la Délégation & oet égard.
7. Demande de crédits et virements.
8. Réglement ot application du droit sur les carrières.
9. Offre de Mr. O. Joseph pour la construction d'une jetée promenade au Port Est.
10. Nominatiou d'un ingéniour on remplacement de Mr. Marichal.
11. Expropriations et excédents do Tanzim.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR.
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronised by officers of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily.

div.head: THE BALL AT ABBEEN. DETAILED REPORT.
div.p: It was announced on Wednesday that the list of invitations to the Ball given By his Highness the Khedive on the 20th instant was closed, over 1,400 invitations having already been issued. Judging from the crowded aspect of the rooms at Abdeen Palace on Friday evening, there can have been but few absentees from this, the most important social function of the Cairo Season.

In view of the enormous number of his guests, the Khedive confined himself to receiving only the most important, among whom H.R.H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Norway and Sweden was, of course, the principal. An Egyptian guard of honor escorted the Prince from Shepheard's Hotel to the palace, where he arrived about half-past ten. Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha and other members of the Khedivial House, the whole of the Diplomatic Corps, the Ministers, and the officers of the Army of Occupation and Egyptian Army, as well as all the leading members of the English and foreign communities, were also present.

The scene was of truly regal magnificence. The gilded saloons brilliantly illuminated, formed a fitting background to the array of gorgeous uniforms and beautiful gowns and the dazzling display of orders and jewels. In the ball-room the private bond of the Khedive played a spirited selection and dancing was kept up with great vigour, Prince Gustavus Adolphus and the members of his suite proving themselves adepts at this fast vanishing art.

In the early part of the evening the Khedivah received a number of the lady guests in a saloon near the ball-room. The Khedive entertained the principal guests of the evening at sapper in a private room, the large supper room was thrown open at midnight and the long tables which lined it on three sides were immediately besieged. In a short time the vast saloon became so crowded that it was difficult to find standing room. The fare provided was of the most sumptuous kind, and almost justified the scramble that was made to procure it.

Amid such a galaxy of pretty dresses it is difficult to single out any for special remark. The Countess of Cromer wore a stately gown of oyster-white' satin; Mme. van der Does de Villebois looked well in a mauve dress, and her daughters wore frocks of pale yellow and pale blue Crepe de Chine respectively. Mrs. Pindlay was in a black dress with sequiu trimming. Lady Palmer wore light blue arranged with cream-colored net. Lady Rogers also wore blue, a striking gown ot dark, 'royal blue' shade, relieved by white muslin and lace at the neck and sleeves. Another most effective gown was worn by Mi»s Slade ; this was of chiffon-velvet in a pale shade of yellow, with a pompadour desigu of red roses and other flowers upon it : made in the princess style, it was bordered by a deep, transparent flounce of black sequined lace over cream colour. Pink was the prevailing color. Mrs. Mellwraith wore it, and Miss Royle's gown of the same hue was very dainty and becoming. Madame Harari Pasba was attired in a smart frock of orange-pink silk. Mrs. Arnold Perry's costume of white mousseline de soie patterned with pale pink roses was admired. Mrs. Hunter wore a picturesque frock of black taffetas, the skirt gathered very full and the bodice à la Marie Antoinette, a band of laoe-like passementerie simulating the wide effect of the fichu which it replaced. Mrs. Watson looked exceedingly well in white satin with flounces of fiue point d Alençon lace, and her war medals as her only ornaments. Mrs. Hooker wore cre'pe de Chine of a deep violet shade. Chiffon-velvet, rucked and tucked, and the skirts arranged in a multiplicity of full, rich folds, was the dernier cri of fashion. Mme. de Martino Pasha wore a handsome pale-blue gown of this material ; Mrs. Campbell was in grey velvet. Taffetas, very sheeny and crisp, was much seen, and soft 'Liberty' satins were also popular. Fine nets were much used, and spotted muslins were greatly in vogue for the toilette de jeune fille. Another pretty girl's frock was of soft blue satin, with a "three-decker' skirt, and a large bunch of Parma violets on the bodice. An exquisite gown was of fine black net over white, arranged in Directoire style, with narrow straps of black velvet ribbon across the front and a garniture of pale blue tru-lover's knots and beautiful white lace.

Among other representatives of the British colony we noticed Mr. and Mrs. A.D. Alban, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald, Mr. and Miss Sheldon Amos, Mr. and Mrs. Anderson, Mr. Aspinall, Dr. Beddoe, Birdwood Boy and Mrs. Birdwood, Mr. and Mrs. Brunyate, the Very Rev. Dean and Mrs. Butcher, Mr. and Mm. Crawley, Mr. and Mrs. Courtenay Clifton, Coles Pasha, Mrs. and the Misses Coles, Mr. and Mrs. Carey, Miss Caillard, Corbet Bey, Mr. and Mrs. Dilbé-roglue, Mr. and Mrs. 8cott-Dalgleisb, Major and Mrs. Garner, Sir William Garstin, Major and Mrs. Graham, Judge Halton, H.E. Harvey Pasha, Mr. and Mrs. Hooker, Mr. and Mrs. Hornblower, Mr. Harrison, H.E. Johnson Pasba and Mrs. Johnson, Major and Mrs. L'Estrango Johnstone, Dr. and Mrs. Keatinge, Mr. and Mrs. Kingsford, Littlewood Bey and Mrs. Littlewood, Dr. and Mrs. Madden, Mr. and Mrs. Mellwraith, Dr. and Mrs. Milton, Mr. and Mrs. Moore, Morice Bey, D. Morice Bey and Mrs. Morice, Sir Colin and Lady Scott-Moncrieff, Mr. and Mrs. Molesworth, Dr. Mu-rison, Dr. and Mrs. Notan, Purvis Bey and Mrs. Purvis, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Perry. Mrs. and Miss Rees, Mr. Reid, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. Rowlatt, Mr. and Miss Royle, Judge Royle, Dr. Sandwith, Dr. and Mrs. Elliot-Smith, Judge and Mrs. Satow, Mr. Scott, Mr. and Mrs. Sheppard, Miss Sheppard, Mr. and Mrs. Villiers Stewart, Mr. and Mrs. Stone. Mr. and Mrs. Thubron, Mr. and Mrs. Verschoyle, Judge and Mrs. Willmore, Mr. Carter Wilson. etc.

Soon after one o'clock the guests began. to depart, but.it was not until a much later hour that the last of them had quitted the palace. The police arrangements for control ling the carriages en route for Abdeen appeared to be very complete ; a strong force commanded the entrance! to Abdeen Street and lined its whole length. The queue was well preserved, but we are inclined to think that the' manipulation of the traffic Joining the main from the side streets was not as perfect as it has been on fermer occasions, and caused some unnecessary delay.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION. DEPARTURE OF R.F.A.
div.p: The 56th Battery, Royal Fiejd Artillery, has received orders to hold itself in readiness to embark at Alexandria for England ou the hired transport "Dilwara" about March 1 next.

The Battery will be replaced in Egypt by No. 2 Company Royal Garrison Artillery, which embarks at Southampton on the "Dil-wara" on or about the 14th proxo. and will arrive at Alexandria about March 1.

The transport "Sicilia" is due at Port Said on the 28th inst., on her way home. Details for passage in this vessel will leave Cairo by the 6.15 p.m. train on the 27th inst., and from Alexandria by the 3 30 p.m.. train same day.

39 N.C.O.'s. and men of the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, with one officer and one N.C.O. in charge, will arrive at Cairo by the 7.20 a.m. train on the 24th inst., from Khartoum, for embarkation in the transport "Sicilia" on the 28th idem, for home.

div.head: PRINCE LEOPOLD AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: H.R.H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg and Dr. Stenhouse are back at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan.

div.head: THE HOLY CARPET.
div.p: Thé Holy Carpet is expected to'arrive At Suez by special train at noon to-morrow. The procession will take place the same afternoon, and subsequently both Carpet and Mahmal will be placed on board the Khédivial Mail liner "Rahmanieh" for conveyance to Jeddah. Two other Khédivial mail steamers,tho "Dakahlieh" and " Neghileh, '' will escort them, having oh board about 2,000 pilgrims. The total number of Egyptians leaving this year for Mecca exceeds 16,000.
Suez is unable to cope with such a rush, and consequently the majority of thé pilgrims have had to camp out of the town, awaiting their turn to leave.
It is noticeable that almost all the Egyptian pilgrims are well armed this year, fearing an attack by the Bedouins en route to the sacredcity.

div.head: KING OSCAR'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: In honor of the birthday of H. M. the King of Sweden and Norway, a dinner was given on Saturday in one of the private saloons of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel by Mr. C. Belinfante Ostberg to H. R. R Prince Gustavus Adolphus of i Sweden and Norway.

There wore present, besides his Royal Highness,LidyCromar, Lady Beatrice Thynne, Boutros Pasha Ghali, General, Mrs. and Miss Slade, De Martino Pasha and Mme. De Mar tino, Ahmed Zeky Pasha, Thurneyassen Pasha, Fabricuis Pasha and Mme. Fabricius, Mr. add Mrs. Brugsch Bey, Baron Ralamb, Captain Swerre, Mr. Borchgrevink, Mr. Monteur, Mr. Heggen, Prof. Jager, Mr. and Mrs. Hoy, Mr. Thister, Mr. and Mrs. Silverhjein, and Mr. Mollen.

Daring dinner Prinoe Gustavus Adolphos proposed the health of H. M. the King of Sweden and Norway, Mr. Belinfante Ostberg proposed that of H. H. the Khedive and also of H. R. H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus, the different national anthems being played.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: According to the official report for the Week ending Saturday, 5 casés of bubonic plague were reported during the past week, 4 at Suez and 1 at Toukh. There were 3 deaths and 2 recoveries.

div.head: CATTLE PLAQUE.
div.p: During the week ending Saturday, 9 deaths only were reported, viz, 1 at Port said, 1 each at Baltim (Markaz Borollos) and Seb-dassis (Markaz Mehallet el Kobra), in the Gharbieh province, and 6 at Shantour, Market Bibeh, Beni Souef. During the corresponding week of 1904, 5,065 deaths were reported. During the past week 884 animals have been inoculated. The total of deaths hitherto reported amounts to 146,791.

div.head: POST OFFICE SAVINGS BANK. EXTENSION OF SERVICE
div.p: From 1st February next the poet offices at the following places will be admitted to transact Savings Bank business Kom Ombo, Omria, Armant, Matarieh (near Manzala), Shibin El Kanater, Bilcas, Matai, Badrashein, Rodah,-Nakada, Abou Matamir, Koubbeh, Minsha, Kutur, arid Ibrahimieh (Ramleb).

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Bishop of Delaware preached at St George s Church, Cairo, yesterday.

The Earl of Crawford, K.T., who is at present staying at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, is having his auxiliary steam yacht "Valhalla" fitted out at Cowes for a long cruise. The vessel is to leave port in a few weeks' time to take her owner on board.
The Hon. Mrs. Ronald Greville has left London for Cannes en route for Egypt
Among the passengers by the Orient liner "Orizaba," due at Port Said on Wednesaday, are the Earl and Countess of Morton ' the Hon. W. F. D. and Lady Esther Smith, and Lord Herschell.

The restaurant at Shepheard's presented an animated appearance on Friday evening, when a number of people were dining there previous to attending the Khedive's Ball H. R. H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway was present. Judge Halton entertained a party of five. We also noticed Mrs. Campbell, with a party, and Mr. Carter Wilson among the diners. This restaurant is, nowadays, one of the pleasantest dining places in Cairo, and the catering and service are in every way equal to what is met with* at the best hotels in Europe.
Capt. H. S. Logan, of the Leicester Regiment, has been appointed Bimbashi in thé 12th Sudanese Battalion.
Lieut. N. McD. Teacher has been appointed Bimbashi in the 10th Sudanese.

We are glad to hear that Mr. James Opie, secretary of the Khédivial Mail Line who has been laid up for the last six weeks at the Deaconesses' Hospital, Alexandria, with a severe attack of smallpox, is now quite convalescent and has left the hospital.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said are Mr. and Mrs. Weekes, Mr. E Pach Mr. J. Sohaar, Mr. & B. Solano, Mr, D. A. Croall, Mr. W. J. Murphy, Mr- B Roy Mr. D. Dirk, Mr. and Mrs. Asldy, Mr. and Mrs. Rendle, Miss Rendle, Miss Brorter, Mr. and Mrs. Hardy, Mr. Zdandevist, Mr. G. Robin, Mr. Daerks, Mr. Kisch.

The following passengers left Shellal by the "Prinoe Abbas" yesterday: Miss Crewdson Miss Lindesay, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Vanderpoel, Mr. and Mrs. Rayual, Mr. and Mrs. Brauer, Miss Waterhouse, Mr. Wm. Johnston, Miss E W. Johnston, Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Congreve, Dr. and Mrs. Dub,Col. Robt. J. Pratt Saunders, C. B., Mrs H. Schou, Capt. Ulgo Bedinello, Miss Augusta Bedinello, Mr. Girardelii, Mr. Swindells, Miss Booth, Mr. F. Maitland, Miss Maitland, Misses Wauchope.

div.head: SAVOY SMALL DANCE.
div.p: Last Saturday's small dance was attended with the usual success. The restaurant was again quite full, and an additional private dining-room bad to be converted into a restaurant to accommodate all who had ordered tables. The list of diners would take up too much space. We may however mention Tueni Bey's party, including Prinoe Djamil Toussouo, Prince Aly Paxil and Princess Fazil, M. Raphael Suares, Mme. and Mile. Sursock, M. and Mme. Michel Tueni The Duke of Montremart was with Prince de Tonnay Charente and Marquis d'Audriffed Pasquier. M. and Mme. Çhoremi were with M. and Mme. Benacbi and M. and Mme. Trehaki. Mr. Thubron had a party of 6 ; Mr. Charles Royle a party of 7, including Miss Royle, Mr. and Mrs. Drummond-Hay, and Dr. and Mrs. Warnock ; M. de Bilinsky a party of 8, including Mr. and Mrs. Adams, Mr. and Mrs. Garret, Miss Pidgeon, and Miss Walford ; and Mr. Goshen's party included Capt. and Mrs. Lyons, Mr. and Mrs. Mansfield de C. Findlay, and Mr. Greville
We also noticed Lady Clarke, Mrs. Jay, Mr. Carter Wilson, Major E Herbert, CoL Watson, M. and Mmb. A. Cattaui, Mme. de Martino Pasha, Dr. Armstrong and a part}- of 6, etc.
The restaurant was also well filled for sapper.

Owing to the increasing success of the Savoy small dances, the management has decided to give an extra small dance on Tuesday, 31st inst. The Saturday's small dance will take place every week as usual.
There will also be a small danoe on Friday evening next, after the concert organised by the Comité des Fétes.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten miniutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

For our position today The highest military authorities are agreed that it is only a question of tine te re we may have to come to grips with Hussta In tact, had it not been for the Japanese throwing down the gauntlet, we might ore this have been at issue with the Bear.
KARACHI VIA THE CANAL..

Foiled for the present by our gallant allies Bo far as Manchuria is concerned, Russia must sooner or later turn her eyes once more to india For such an invasion she requires no Rodjestvensky. Her troops are practically on the frontier, her railways are ready to be laid, and the plan of campaign has been carefully prepared. To resist such an attack, instant reinforcements from this country would be absolutely necessary. That means fast transports to Bombay and Karachi rid the Suez Canal.
A POSSIBILITY

Now, without suggesting for a moment the possibility of any sympathetic laxity on the part of the custodians of the Canal, it is obvious that "a regrettable incident" in the shape of an "accidental" obstruction of the waterway might Basily be brought about at a crisis when delay would be of vital importance to us; in fact, if my memory serves me correctly, something of the kind did actually occur during the period of the Arabi troubles, when troops from India were delayed by the stranding of a merchant Steamer which was not removed until Lord Alcester threatened to send up a force of blue- jackets to do the work. It is quite true that our fleets can protect the ends of the Canal, hat it is not at the ends the mischief would ceur, but in the fairway, open to merchant ships of all nations.
CANAL COMPANY'S DUTY.
Given an Fat.
the

This in no imaginary picture. Is it surprising, therefore, that I pass over the claims of shipowners and other in the commercial world for better treatment from these Canal directors, and place in the front rank the imperative necessity, from the point of view of our national existence, for the construction of an inde pendent Canal across the Isthmus of Suez 1 I go further, and say that only by some such independent means of communication is peace at all likely to be maintained. all British right of way to Kussia will think twice before commencing operations against India, but so long as we are restricted to one waterway, and that not controlled by ourselves, the temptation to Kussin to gratify her life-long ambition a most rresistible. Now a glance at THE IMPERIAL SITUATION. Consider the extraordinary anomaly of the position. We as a country do the bulk of the Fastern trade both in ships and merchandise, the ports of destination being in most cases those belonging to the Empire: India, with its £75,000,000 of trade, the Straits; the treaty ports of China, commercially almostentirely ours Australia, and New Zealand.

The whole of this immense trade, with the exception of a considerable slice which the exactions of the Canal Company seem to have driven via the Cape, is condemned to pass tinough this narrow isthmus, controlled and poled by aliens, leaving behind it as toll the large sam of over one hundred millions of franes annually The very country through which the Canal is cut is now, in effect, British soil. What country except poor patient England would stand it No one seeks to deprive the descendants of the courageous Lesseps and their compatriots of their concession, though the said concession was granted by a Sultan of Turkey long before the British -occupation of Egypt, and under such circumstances some of our neighbours might not be so particular, but it is quite another matter to say that no other waterway must be built. A man can do what he likes with his own.
THE PRESENT COMPANY

have no exclusive right to the sands and lakes of the isthmus, they never had. Therefore, if grievances exist and I gather that they do -the Company must expect opposition. Commercially speaking, Egypt cannot fail to benefit by a multiplicity of waterways, and her sagacious ruler, Lord Cromer, may be trusted to look after the interests of a country which has progressed so famously under his able régime. Egypt has been very badly treated by the Canal. Compelled, owing to the heavy mortalty, to withdraw the corvée, or forced labour, the Canal Company made Egypt pay some £1,200,000 damages. India can only view with alarm the continuance of the present exorbitant impost on her trade; and Lord Curzon, than whom no man has a better grasp ot his Empire's immense potentialities, would, I feel sure, be the first to advocate
A BRITISH CANAL

with moderate dues. In regard to Australasia, we are looking for a commercial boud of union with the mother country, and yet we tolerate this toll of 4s. to 88. per ton on her imports and our exports. There is no question here as to who benefits by the tax; it is the Canal Company. Apart from these all important considerations, the British, and indeed the German and French, shipowner considers that on more than one point the Canal directors have broken faith with him, and the present strained position has arisen. I sincerely trust the matter will be forced to a conclusion. It is not a reduction in dues and amelioration of condi ons that are wanted. I observe the directors think to appease their clients by the offer of a reduction of half a frauc per ton. This from the present charge of 84 trans Could any thing be more ridiculous! It is not a reduction n dues that is wanted. It is a new C'anal However important from 24 national and Imperial point of view this may be, we are a commercial people, and it will be on a commercial basis
THE BRITISH CANAL

will be built. A proposition that shows a sound 8 to 10 per cent. return, taking only half the present dues and half the present tonnage using the Canal, cannot fail to appeal to the commercial instincts of this country, and, backed by the vast shipping and trading interests of the kingdom, counselled by the heads of Empire beyond the seas, and commended by the highest naval and military authorities at home, it would be a bold Ministry which, for the sake of difficulties possibly temporary, would venture to withhold its sanction from such a scheme.
SPORT AND PLAY.
RACING AT KHARTOUM.
(PROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)

Khartoum, January 13. The Khartoum Second Winter Meeting was held to-day in delightfully cool but sunny weather. H.E the Governor General, who drove on the course in a 30 h.-p. Wolseley motor car, as well as an unusually large number of the fair sex, honored the proceedings with their presence. The sport on the whole was somewhat lacking in interest, as on the form exposed at the last meeting, four out of the six events open to members of the Khartoum Racing Club were foregone conclusions. Mr. Trafford again won three races, whilst the winners of the other three all hailed from
Shendi.
